find the picture, I cut it out and put it somewhere.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] anyone for a piece of history
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Gordon, I d like to see the pictures of Choshu-ya s koshirae if you can do it. I m in the middle of a shodo course at Japan Society in NYC and plan to keep
messages.messageBody:
Hi Gordon,
I'd like to see the pictures of Choshu-ya's koshirae if you can do it.

I'm in the middle of a shodo course at Japan Society in NYC and plan to keep at it. Token and kodogu are hard enough, but the koshirae worksheet descriptions are going to be a monster challenge. Edo period machibori kodogu kantei is also going to take a lot of work. I don't know about four years but it sure is motivating.

Jim



Hi Jim,

You're welcome. Maybe soon we can have katakana on our fittings
kanteisho!! Since this information didn't go out on this list, let me
add that kenkyu-in is the first step to becoming a member of the shinsa
team. All of the members of the present team went through the ranks.
The next step is shinsa-in hosa, which means an assistant to the shinsa
team. Assistants should fill out the working papers -- in Japanese. I
could somewhat manage this, but in the end, I was given a break. The
third stage is full shinsa team member. This all typically takes about
four years or so from kenkyu-in to full shinsa team member.

I will also try and scan a photo of Choshu-ya's koshirae. I don't think
it sold.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] anyone for a piece of history
messages.messageBody:
Thanks. Too bad.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] anyone for a piece of history
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, You re welcome. Maybe soon we can have katakana on our fittings kanteisho!! Since this information didn t go out on this list, let me add that
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim,

You're welcome. Maybe soon we can have katakana on our fittings
kanteisho!! Since this information didn't go out on this list, let me
add that kenkyu-in is the first step to becoming a member of the shinsa
team. All of the members of the present team went through the ranks.
The next step is shinsa-in hosa, which means an assistant to the shinsa
team. Assistants should fill out the working papers -- in Japanese. I
could somewhat manage this, but in the end, I was given a break. The
third stage is full shinsa team member. This all typically takes about
four years or so from kenkyu-in to full shinsa team member.

I will also try and scan a photo of Choshu-ya's koshirae. I don't think
it sold.

>

>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] anyone for a piece of history
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon, I suspect that there may be iron tsunagi in some of those koshirae.  The older one with the also unillustrated ...mune saku, Nanbokucho blade was the
messages.messageBody:
Gordon,
I suspect that there may be iron tsunagi in some of those koshirae. The older one with the also unillustrated "...mune saku, Nanbokucho blade" was the one that was I was going on about. The "younger" one is pretty interesting, too. I wish I had seen Choshu-ya's koshirae, but I'd like to have seen a complete example of the older one even more. But, I stayed home instead.

BTW, I got a copy from Ian on the yahoo nihonto list of your public mention of the kenkyu-in thing there. Thanks for the recognition. I have a lot of work to do.

Jim



Hi Jim,



There is one at Choshu-ya. It was out on display last weekend. It is very
similar to the first one listed below except that the kozuka and kogai are
intact. Absolutely killer. I wonder why the Tegai Kanenaga inside is not
shown? Or is that a stupid question?



Gordon



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Yes, the second one. I won't be bidding, but I'd like to have a look at it.

Jim

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, November 07, 2003 12:48 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] anyone for a piece of history


Sometimes the motif of that type of pommel is identified as a phoenix, at other times as a dragon depending on the visible details.

There is also an interesting early koshigatana koshirae in that sale, although unfortunately there are some replacement parts done in silver. I don't recall the lot number and my copy of the catalog seems to be in hiding.

Jim

messages.messageBody:
Sometimes the motif of that type of pommel is identified as a phoenix, at other times as a dragon depending on the visible details.

There is also an interesting early koshigatana koshirae in that sale, although unfortunately there are some replacement parts done in silver. I don't recall the lot number and my copy of the catalog seems to be in hiding.

Jim


Cheers Jim, great to see the old pieces being preserved. Listed at Christie's is this tachi pommel as well. Is that something like a Pheoniz or bird of some kind ?.

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, November 07, 2003 9:31 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] anyone for a piece of history


Yes, it's mine. Thanks. There are much better examples including some that show areas of what appear to be the original surface and very nicely done hirazogan (no doubt revealed only after very careful cleaning).

Some years ago John Badenhop had a museum journal in Japanese that showed these guards being cleaned with a plasma etching technique. The chemistry was presumably chosen to etch the rust while having some reasonable selectivity to the unoxidized iron and the inlay. I only got a quick look, so I don't know the details.

Here's a soft metal example, too: http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/irogane.htm

and some more fuzzy photos from pieces in museums:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kofun2.htm
http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kofun.htm

Some of the blades of this period also show extensive inlay in silver and sometimes gold. Some of these sat unrecognized for years before they were cleaned sufficiently to reveal the inlay. "Windows on the Japanese Past: Studies in Archaeology and Prehistory" has an article or two on these swords as I recall. There's even a piece there by some guy named Bleed, although not sword related.

Jim

messages.msgSnippet: Yes, it s mine.  Thanks.  There are much better examples including some that show areas of what appear to be the original surface and very nicely done
messages.messageBody:
Yes, it's mine. Thanks. There are much better examples including some that show areas of what appear to be the original surface and very nicely done hirazogan (no doubt revealed only after very careful cleaning).

Some years ago John Badenhop had a museum journal in Japanese that showed these guards being cleaned with a plasma etching technique. The chemistry was presumably chosen to etch the rust while having some reasonable selectivity to the unoxidized iron and the inlay. I only got a quick look, so I don't know the details.

Here's a soft metal example, too: http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/irogane.htm

and some more fuzzy photos from pieces in museums:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kofun2.htm
http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kofun.htm

Some of the blades of this period also show extensive inlay in silver and sometimes gold. Some of these sat unrecognized for years before they were cleaned sufficiently to reveal the inlay. "Windows on the Japanese Past: Studies in Archaeology and Prehistory" has an article or two on these swords as I recall. There's even a piece there by some guy named Bleed, although not sword related.

Jim



agreed Jim, even in this one condition, it is pretty cool, that is like app 1200 years old, amazing. Is that one on your page in your collection ?, it is excellent.

Rich
